"Ejaculation Frequency and Subsequent Risk of Prostate Cancer"{{cite journal | last = Leitzmann MD | first = Michael F | first2 = Elizabeth A., ScD | last2 = Platz | first3 = Meir J., MD | last3 = Stampfer | first4 = Walter C., MD | last4 = Willett | first5 = Edward, MD | last5 = Giovannucci | title = Ejaculation Frequency and Subsequent Risk of Prostate Cancer | journal = [[Journal of the American Medical Association]] | volume = 291 | issue = 13 | pages = 1578–86 | date = 7 April 2004 | language = | url = http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=198487 | jstor = | issn = | doi = 10.1001/jama.291.13.1578 | id = | mr = | zbl = | jfm = | accessdate = 9 February 2013 | pmid=15069045}} and "Sexual Factors and Prostate Cancer"{{cite journal | last1 = Giles | first1 = Graham G., BSc, MSc, PhD | last2 = Severi | first2 = G. | last3 = English | first3 = D.R. | last4 = McCredie | first4 = M.R. | last5 = Borland | first5 = R. | last6 = Boyle | first6 = P. | last7 = Hopper | first7 = J.L. | title = Sexual factors and prostate cancer | journal = [[BJUI|BJU International]] | volume = 92 | issue = 3 | pages = 211–16 | date = August 2003 | language = | url = | jstor = | issn = | doi =10.1046/j.1464-410X.2003.04319.x | id = | mr = | zbl = | jfm = | pmid=12887469}} suggest that frequent ejaculation over a lifetime offers some protection against prostate cancer. The US study involving "29,342 US men aged 46 to 81 years" suggest that "high ejaculation frequency was related to decreased risk of total prostate cancer". An Australian study involving "1,079 men with prostate cancer and 1,259 healthy men" found that "there is evidence that the more frequently men ejaculate between the ages of 20 and 50, the less likely they are to develop prostate cancer": {{quote|[T]he protective effect of ejaculation is greatest when men in their twenties ejaculated on average seven or more times a week. This group were one-third less likely to develop aggressive prostate cancer when compared with men who ejaculated less than three times a week at this age.{{cite web | title = New findings on prostate cancer risk and sexual activity | work = Cancer Council Victoria website | publisher = Cancer Council Victoria | date = 17 July 2003 | url = http://www.cancervic.org.au/media/media-releases/archived_media_releases/2003_media_releases/july_2003/new_findings_on_prostate_cancer_risk_and_sexual_activity.html | doi = | accessdate = 9 February 2013}}}} ==Other animals== {{see also|Semen collection#By species}} [[File:Spontaneous-Ejaculation-in-a-Wild-Indo-Pacific-Bottlenose-Dolphin-(Tursiops-aduncus)-pone.0072879.s001.ogv|thumb|thumbtime=5|An ejaculation by a male [[Indo-Pacific bottlenose dolphin]]]] In mammals and birds, multiple ejaculation is commonplace.{{cite book|first=Robert L. | last = Smith|title=Sperm Competition and the Evolution of Animal Mating systems|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OIh4DX7tk_0C&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=ejaculation|accessdate=19 April 2013|date=28 December 1984|publisher=Elsevier|isbn=978-0-323-14313-4}}{{cite book|author=P. Michael Conn|title=Paradigms for the Study of Behavior|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Xp9GBQAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=ejaculation|date=22 October 2013|publisher=Elsevier Science|isbn=978-1-4832-6937-5}} During copulation, each side of a [[short-beaked echidna]]'s penis is used alternately, with the other half being shut down between ejaculations.Johnston S.D., Smith B., Pyne M., Stenzel D., and Holt W.V. One-Sided Ejaculation of Echidna Sperm Bundles (''Tachyglossus aculeatus''). ''Am. Nat.'' 2007. Vol. 170, p. E000. [AN:42629 ] {{doi|10.1086/522847}} In [[stallion]]s, ejaculation is accompanied by a motion of the tail known as "tail flagging".{{cite book | first1 = Juan C., Ph.D. | last1 = Samper | first2 = Jonatjhan F. | last2 = Pycock | first3 = Angus O. | last3 = McKinnon | title=Current therapy in equine reproduction|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1vAJ2lbypRMC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=ejaculation%20flagging|accessdate=18 April 2013|year=2007|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn=978-0-7216-0252-3}} When [[Gray wolf#Copulation|a male wolf ejaculates]], his final [[pelvic thrust]] may be slightly prolonged.{{cite book | first1 = L. David | last1 = Mech|first2 = Luigi | last2 = Boitani|title=Wolves: Behavior, Ecology, and Conservation|url=https://books.google.com/?id=_mXHuSSbiGgC&pg=PA44&dq=wolf+ejaculation#v=onepage&q=wolf%20ejaculation|accessdate=19 April 2013|date=1 October 2010|publisher=University of Chicago Press|isbn=978-0-226-51698-1|pages=44–}} A male [[rhesus monkey]] usually ejaculates less than 15 seconds after [[sexual penetration]].{{cite book|title=The pursuit of pleasure|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LiyrEhQPmRsC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=monkey%20ejaculate%20withdraw|accessdate=19 April 2013|year=1992|publisher=Transaction Publishers|isbn=978-1-4128-3867-2}} The first report and footage of [[spontaneous ejaculation]] in an aquatic mammal was recorded in a wild [[Indo-Pacific bottlenose dolphin]] near [[Mikura Island]], Japan in 2012.{{cite journal|last=Morisaka|first=Tadamichi|last2= Sakai | first2 = Mai | last3 = Kogi | first3 = Kazunobu | last4 = Nakasuji | first4 = Akane | last5 = Sakakibara | first5 = Kasumi | last6 = Kasanuki | first6 = Yuria | last7 = Yoshioka | first7 = Motoi | last8 = Sakamoto | first8 = Kentaro Q. | title=Spontaneous Ejaculation in a Wild Indo-Pacific Bottlenose Dolphin (Tursiops aduncus)|journal=PLoS ONE|date=27 August 2013|volume=8|issue=8|pages=e72879|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0072879| pmid=24015280 | pmc=3755988}} In horses, sheep, and cattle, ejaculation lasts for several seconds or fractions of a second, but in [[boar]]s, it can last for 10–30 minutes{{cite book|author1=Sergi Bonet|author2=Isabel Casas|author3=William V. Holt|author4=Marc Yeste|title=Boar Reproduction: Fundamentals and New Biotechnological Trends|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ta9GAAAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=(ejaculation%20OR%20penis%20OR%20ejaculated)|date=1 February 2013|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=978-3-642-35049-8}} or 5–10 minutes.{{cite book|author=Heriberto Rodriguez-Martinez|title=Control of Pig Reproduction VIII|url=https://books.google.com/?id=em-TrWgAFSYC&pg=PA15&dq=boar+ejaculation+penis+semen#v=onepage&q=(ejaculation%20OR%20penis%20OR%20ejaculated)|date=1 April 2010|publisher=Nottingham University Press|isbn=978-1-907284-53-3|pages=15–}} Ejaculation in boars is stimulated when the spiral-shaped glans penis interlocks with the female's cervix.{{cite book|author1=Bonnie S. Dunbar|author2=M.G. O'Rand|title=A Comparative Overview of Mammalian Fertilization|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zjnnBwAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=(ejaculation%20OR%20ejaculated)|date=29 June 2013|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=978-1-4757-8982-9}} A mature boar can produce {{Convert|250–300|ml||abbr=on}} of semen during one ejaculation. In llamas and alpacas, ejaculation occurs continuously during copulation.{{cite book|author1=Chris Cebra|author2=David E. Anderson|author3=Ahmed Tibary|author4=Robert J. Van Saun|author5=LaRue Willard Johnson|title=Llama and Alpaca Care: Medicine, Surgery, Reproduction, Nutrition, and Herd Health|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8sU0AwAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=ejaculation|date=15 February 2014|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn=978-0-323-24291-2}} The semen of male dogs is ejaculated in three separate fractions.{{cite book|author=Margaret V. Root Kustritz|title=The Dog Breeder's Guide to Successful Breeding and Health Management|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rqIa-9jew_MC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=(ejaculation%20OR%20ejaculated)|date=2006|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn=978-1-4160-3139-0|accessdate=2015-10-21}} The third fraction is produced during the [[copulatory tie]], and consists mainly of prostatic fluid.{{cite book|author1=Edward C. Feldman|author2=Richard William Nelson|title=Canine and Feline Endocrinology and Reproduction|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=elPuvsucuY8C&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=(ejaculation%20OR%20ejaculated)|date=2004|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn=978-0-7216-9315-6|accessdate=2015-10-21}} ==See also== {{Portal|Sexuality}} * [[Insemination]] * [[Aspermia]] * [[Coitus interruptus]] * [[Coitus reservatus]] * [[Cum shot]] * {{Infobox Governor |image = Eugenio Hernandez Flores.jpg |name= Eugenio Hernández Flores |caption= |office= [[Governor of Tamaulipas]] |term_start= February 5, 2005 |term_end= December 31, 2010 |predecessor= [[Tomás Yarrington]] |successor= [[Egidio Torre Cantú]] |birth_date= {{Birth date and age|1959|10|17|mf=y}} |birth_place= [[Ciudad Victoria]], [[Tamaulipas]] |death_date= |death_place= |spouse= Adriana González |profession= [[Civil engineer]] |party= [[Institutional Revolutionary Party]] [[File:PRI logo (Mexico).svg|20px]] |footnotes= }} '''Eugenio Javier Hernández Flores''' (born October 17, 1959 in [[Ciudad Victoria]], [[Tamaulipas]]), is a [[Mexican people|Mexican]] politician affiliated with the [[Institutional Revolutionary Party]] (PRI). He was the mayor of [[Ciudad Victoria]] from 2001 to 2004 and Governor of the state of [[Tamaulipas]] from 2004 to 2010, and was also federal deputy in 2000 and coordinator of the Financial Committee of [[Tomas Yarrington]] during his campaign. On May 27, 2015, he was indicted on charges of [[money laundering]] alongside his brother-in-law [[Oscar Gomez Guerra]] by the [[United States Department of Justice]] (USDOJ).<ref name="justiceformergovernor"/>
== Personal life == He is fourth child of Eugenio Hernández Balboa and Susana Flores Fernández. He studied civil engineering at the [[Monterrey Institute of Technology and Higher Education]]. He is married to Adriana González de Hernández with whom he has four children. In his earliest professional life he worked in the construction industry, where he became President of the Chamber of the Mexican Construction Industry and President of the municipal Commission the Water and Sewer System.<ref name=semb>{{cite web|url=http://www.gobierno.com.mx/estado/tamaulipas/|title=Semblanza del gobernador|work=Gobierno de Tamaulipas. |year=2013|accessdate=8 May 2013| language=spanish }}</ref>
== Political career == He was affiliated with Institutional Revolutionary Party in 1997.<ref name=cand>{{cite web|url=http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2004/06/27/030n1est.php?origen=estados.php&fly=1|title=Convención del PRI elige a Hernández Flores candidato a la gubernatura de Tamaulipas|author=Sánchez Treviño, Martin|publisher=La Jornada|date=26 June 2004| language=spanish}}</ref> In 1999 during the presidential campaign of [[Francisco Labastida Ochoa]], Eugenio Hernández was appointed as state’s campaign coordinator in Tamaulipas. The same year, he was elected as general secretary of the Directive Committee of the PRI party.<ref name=semb/>
In year 2000 he was elected federal deputiy of the V Electoral District, in this way he became part of [[LVIII Legislature of the Mexican Congress|LVIII Legislatura]] where he was member in the Housing Commission and in Water resources one, as such he introduced the bill of reformation of article 46 of the Housing Workers Fund Law.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.diputados.gob.mx/cesop/Comisiones/6_vivienda.htm|title=Desempeño legislativo. Iniciativas turnadas a la Comisión de Vivienda durante la LVIII legislatura|date=5 June 2006|work=Chamber of Deputies|author=Centro de Estudios Sociales y de Opinión Pública|accessdate=10 May 2013|language=spanish|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004220645/http://www.diputados.gob.mx/cesop/Comisiones/6_vivienda.htm|archivedate=4 October 2013|df=}}</ref> In that year he requested a permission of license as deputy to become a candidate in Ciudad Victoria’s mayor election, which he won. He took the mayor’s post in 2001.
=== Tamaulipas Governor === In PRI’s internal election he was appointed as candidate of that party to participate in the Tamaulipas Governor election to be run in June 26, 2004.<ref name=cand/> Thus, he took part in Governor’s election against the opponent candidates: [[Gustavo Cárdenas Gutiérrez|Gustavo Cárdenas]] of PAN, Álvaro Garza Cantú of the alliance formed by [[Party of the Democratic Revolution]] and [[Citizens' Movement (Mexico)|Convergencia]], and Bruno Álvarez of the [[Labor Party (Mexico)|Labor Party]]. The elections were run on November 14 and Eugenio Hernández was elected governor with 58.26% of all votes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2004/11/15/007n1est.php?origen=estados.php&fly=1|title=Sin problemas, el PRI gana en Tamaulipas|author=Martínez, Fabiola y Sánchez, Martín|date=15 November 2004|language=spanish}}</ref>
He began his government on February 5, 2005. In May of that year, he introduced his Plan of Development of the State for the period 2005-2010, which was the guide for the public policy throughout his period of government,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cronica.com.mx/notas/2005/183656.html|title=El gobernador de Tamaulipas presenta el Plan Estatal de Desarrollo 2005-2010|publisher=Crónica|date=28 May 2005|language=Spanish}}</ref> his government was based in three strategic lines: I) Social Prosperity; II) Competitivity and Productivity; e III) Strong institutions and Government of results.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lib.utexas.edu/benson/lagovdocs/mexico/tamaulipas/ped/ped2005-2010tamaulipas.pdf|title=Plan Estatal de Desarrollo 2005-2011|author=Gobierno de Tamaulipas|year=2005|accessdate=14 May 2013|work=Texas University|language=Spanish}}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> [[File:Hernández Flores en cena con Barack Obama.jpg|thumb|Eugenio Hernández Flores in a meeting with US president [[Barack Obama]] and the president of Mexico [[Felipe Calderón]] in 2009.]]
His government was relevant for the constant fight against organized crime. He promoted an alliance with the rest of Mexican border states, the [[Municipalities of Mexico|municipalities]] and federal government to avoid the traffic of arms and people between the United States and Mexico.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://impacto.mx/nacional/12q/fortalecen-lucha-anticrimen-en-el-noreste|title=Fortalecen luchaanticrimen en el Noreste|publisher=Impacto|date=24 November 2010|language=spanish|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004231451/http://impacto.mx/nacional/12q/fortalecen-lucha-anticrimen-en-el-noreste|archivedate=4 October 2013|df=}}</ref> As the results of this agreement, it was allowed to the Mexican army to settle down in Tamaulipas with thousands of troops to manage the fight against drug dealers and look after custom services in Tamaulipas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2010/02/28/politica/005n1pol|title=Ejército y Marina se encargarán de lasacciones contra el crimen en Tamaulipas|author=Gustavo Castillo y Jesús Aranda|date=28 February 2010|publisher=Periódico La Jornada|language=Spanish}}</ref> He expressed his agreement to make a public ballot question to put on people’s consideration the possibility to impose the [[capital punishment]] as penalty for [[kidnapping]] and to stop the violence from crime. At the final stage of his government, Hernández Flores remarked that 42% of police members have been destituted as they were untrustworthy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2010/12/09/estados/041n1est|title=Encara Tamaulipas violenciainédita: Eugenio Hernández|author=Martín Sánchez Treviño|date= 9 December 2010|publisher=La Jornada|language=spanish}}</ref>
With respect to relations with the US states bordering Tamaulipas, Hernández Flores was a principal critic of the immigration laws applied in Texas. He was against the [[Mexico–United States barrier|barrier]] raised between the countries during his term in office.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2008/05/02/index.php?section=politica&article=018n2pol|title=El nuevo muro humilla a México: Hernández Flores|date=2 May 2008|language=Spanish}}</ref> In economic matters, he promoted the internal oil investments in Tamaulipas and the creation of jobs coming from that industry. Thus, when [[PEMEX|PetroleosMexicanos company]] announced that another refinery was going to be built in Mexico, Hernández Flores proposed that it be sited at Tamaulipas. It was ultimately decided that the refinery be built in Hidalgo state.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2009/03/26/economia/029n1eco|title=Tamaulipas es, con Altamira, la opción ideal para la nueva refinería: Eugenio Hernández|date=26 March 2009|publisher=Periódico La Jornada|language=Spanish}}</ref>
During his term as governor, [[Fitch Group|Fitch Ratings]] recognized excellent financial management in Tamaulipas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2010/10/12/politica/016n2pol|title=Tamaulipas consolida su "muy alta calificación crediticia"|date=12 October 2010|publisher=Periódico La Jornada|language=spanish}}</ref> Nevertheless, after his government he was accused of generating an over-indebtedness.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.excelsior.com.mx/node/714124|title=Tamaulipas está endeudado hasta el año 2027|date=14 February 2011|author1=Reyes Cruz |author2=Juan Manuel |publisher=Excelsior|language=spanish}}</ref>
==Indictment== {{Expand section|date=March 2017}} On May 27, 2015, Hernández Flores was indicted on charges of [[money laundering]] alongside his brother-in-law [[Oscar Gomez Guerra]] by the [[United States Department of Justice]] (USDOJ), making him a "fugitive" wanted by the United States.<ref name="justiceformergovernor">{{cite web|title=Former Tamaulipas Governor Indicted in Money Laundering Scheme with Brother-in-Law|url=https://www.justice.gov/usao-sdtx/pr/former-tamaulipas-governor-indicted-money-laundering-scheme-brother-law|website=United States Department of Justice|accessdate=March 5, 2017|date=June 19, 2015}}</ref> The charges concern a US$30 million sum plus US$2 million invested in three properties in [[McAllen, Texas]] and a fourth property in [[Austin, Texas]].<ref name="justiceformergovernor"/>

Danish Amateur Radio Experimenters |image = EDR_logo.png |image_border = |size = 80px |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = EDR |motto = |formation = August 15, 1927 |extinction = |type = [[Non-profit organization]] |status = |purpose = Advocacy, Education |headquarters = |location = [[Odense]], [[Denmark]] |region_served = [[Denmark]] |membership = |language = [[Danish language|Danish]] |leader_title = President |leader_name = Finn Madsen OZ1AHV |main_organ = |affiliations = [[International Amateur Radio Union]] |num_staff = |budget = |website = http://www.edr.dk/ |remarks = }} The '''Experimenterende Danske Radioamatører''' ('''EDR''') (in [[English language|English]], '''Danish Amateur Radio Experimenters''') is a national [[non-profit organization]] for [[amateur radio]] enthusiasts in [[Denmark]]. Membership benefits of EDR include the sponsorship of [[amateur radio operating award]]s and radio [[contesting|contests]], and a [[QSL card|QSL]] bureau for those members who communicate with [[amateur radio operator]]s in other countries. EDR represents the interests of Danish amateur radio operators before Danish and international telecommunications regulatory authorities.Experimenterende Danske Radioamatører (2008). [http://www.edr.dk/EDR.aspx "EDR"]. Retrieved Aug. 14, 2008. EDR is the national member society representing Denmark in the [[International Amateur Radio Union]].International Amateur Radio Union (2008). [http://www.iaru.org/iaru-soc.html "Member Societies"]. Retrieved Aug. 1, 2008. EDR publishes a membership magazine called ''[[OZ (radio amateur magazine)|OZ]]''. == See also == *[[International Amateur Radio Union]] == References == {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Experimenterende Danske Radioamatorer}} [[Category:International Amateur Radio Union member societies|Denmark]] [[Category:Clubs and societies in Denmark]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1927]] [[Category:1927 establishments in Denmark]] [[Category:Organizations based in Odense]] {{Amateur-radio-stub}} {{Denmark-org-stub}}

{{Other uses|Field day (disambiguation){{!}}Field day}} {{Refimprove|date=August 2017}} __NOTOC__ [[Image:Horseshoes2.jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[Horseshoe pitching]] contest at the annual field day of the [[Farm Security Administration|FSA]] farmworkers community, [[Yuma, Arizona]] (1942)]]
A '''field day''' is a large [[trade show]] for [[agriculture|agricultural]] industry and equipment, especially for [[broadacre]] [[Agriculture|farming]]. It contrasts with an [[agricultural show]] in that a show focuses on livestock and judging, a field day focuses on equipment, demonstrations and processes.
A field day may include events such as [[ploughing]] competitions not usually associated with shows due to the larger space required. The events are good sources of agricultural information, as organizers can arrange for guest speakers to talk on a range of topics.
==Field days by country== ===Australia=== {{main|Field days in Australia}}
===New Zealand=== New Zealand [[National Agricultural Fieldays]] is held at Mystery Creek, [[Hamilton, New Zealand]] and attracts 1,000 exhibitors and over 115,000 visitors through its gates. Smaller shows, held annually in New Zealand's towns and communities, are generally called Agricultural and Pastoral shows (A&P shows).
===Ukraine=== On August 28, 2013 Mykolaiv National Agrarian University started a new tradition of field day in Ukraine.
On August 28, 2013 Field Day on technology of vegetables cultivation was held at the Educational, Scientific and Practical Center of Mykolayiv NAU together with the "S-Rostok company" and with participation of Mykola Kruglov, the Head of Mykolayiv Regional State Administration.
Genius lies in simplicity, as well as the Mykolayiv NAU and the "S-Rostok" company's idea to combine efforts of university science, agrarian education and business in order to realize the common pilot project. The point is – the creation of experimental demonstration field with nearly 150 new breeds and hybrids of vegetable crops of the best-known world producers.
The world-famous companies in vegetable seed business from France, Germany, Italy, Spain, Japan, the USA, Israel, and the Netherlands (16 countries in total) participated in the event.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en-news.mnau.edu.ua/2013/10/the-field-day-at-the-mykolayiv-nau.html|title=The Field Day at the Mykolaiv National Agrarian University – Agroexperiment 2013!|website=En-news.mnau.edu.ua|accessdate=31 August 2017}}</ref>

{{Update|inaccurate=yes|date=March 2013}} The '''Filipino Veterans Fairness Act''' is the name of a number of acts that have been introduced to the [[United States Congress]] in both the [[United States House of Representatives]] and the [[United States Senate]] since the [[103rd United States Congress|103rd Congress]] in 1993.<ref name=s120>{{Citation |url=http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=s103-120 |title=S. 120 (103rd): Filipino Veterans Equity Act of 1993 |publisher=GovTrack.us |accessdate=2007-01-13}}</ref> Since then, nearly every session of Congress has seen a new version of the bill introduced. The purpose of these bills is to amend [[Title 38 of the United States Code]] to grant [[citizenship]] to Filipinos who have completed an enlistment in the [[American Armed Forces]]; at least some versions of this bill would grant citizenship to other foreign nationals under the same provisions.<ref name= "dunnigan">[[Jim Dunnigan|Dunnigan, James F.]] and [[Albert Nofi|Nofi, Albert A.]] "Dirty Little Secrets". Quill (1990) {{ISBN|0-688-11270-6}}</ref> Currently, every version of the bill introduced has died in committee. Despite this, the bill has been re-introduced in nearly every session of Congress since 1993.<ref name=hr760>{{Citation |url=http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h110-760 |title=H.R. 760: Filipino Veterans Equity Act of 2007 |publisher=GovTrack.us |accessdate=2007-01-13}}</ref>
== History of the ''[[Veteranos]]''== [[File:Veterans333jf.JPG|thumb|right|150px|1995 [[World War II]] [[Aurora (province)|Aurora]] Veterans monument and memorial at Quezon Park, [[Baler, Aurora]].]] Filipinos have fought as members of the American armed forces for over a century. Originally this was limited to U.S. nationals, Filipinos that had emigrated to the U.S. Under a special provision of the Base Agreement between the U.S. and the Republic of the Philippines, which allowed the U.S. to build bases and station troops in the host country, Filipino nationals are allowed to enlist in the U.S. armed forces.<ref name="dunnigan"/> This arrangement is unique, under normal circumstances foreign nationals are not allowed to enlist in U.S. armed forces unless they are resident aliens of the United States. However, since Filipino enlistees are neither U.S. nationals nor resident aliens, they are not granted citizenship upon completion of their first enlistment, and are entitled to fewer benefits.<ref name="dunnigan"/> Proponents of the bill often point out that thousands of Filipinos have enlisted so far (including many in the [[United States Army Forces in the Far East]] in [[World War II]]) and that ninety-percent choose to reenlist,<ref name="dunnigan"/> even though they are the only non-citizen veterans that are not given citizenship upon completion of their enlistment. Since the bill has never made it out of committee, it is unknown what arguments might be used against it. The bill is widely supported by the [[Filipino-American]] community, as well as a US Conference of Mayors unanimous vote of passage for a resolution authored by Filipino-American Mayor [[Christopher Cabaldon]] that called for the full support of the Filipino Veterans Fairness Act. Most versions have been introduced by congressmen with Filipino-American communities among their constituents.<ref name=s623>{{Citation |url=http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=s105-623 |title=S. 623 (105th): Filipino Veterans Equity Act of 1997 |publisher=GovTrack.us |accessdate=2007-01-13}}</ref>
== The Bill == Since 1993, versions of this bill have been introduced to congress by members of both parties.<ref name=hr491>{{Citation |url=http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h107-491 |title=H.R. 491 (107th): Filipino Veterans Equity Act of 2001 |publisher=GovTrack.us |accessdate=2007-01-13}}</ref><ref name=s57>{{Citation |url=http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=s110-57 |title=S. 57: Filipino Veterans Equity Act of 2007 |publisher=GovTrack.us |accessdate=2007-01-13}}</ref> All but the most recent version are dead, most died in committee before even being scheduled for debate.<ref name=hr4574>{{Citation |url=http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h109-4574 |title=H.R. 4574 (109th): Filipino Veterans Equity Act of 2006 |publisher=GovTrack.us |accessdate=2007-01-13}}</ref> The bill is typically assigned to a veterans affairs committee after its introduction. The most recent version, introduced in the House of Representatives in 2007 is in committee and was scheduled for debate. It was never voted upon.<ref name=hr760 />
In June 2007, Mayor [[Christopher Cabaldon]] of [[West Sacramento, California|West Sacramento]] proposed a resolution to the United States [[Conference of Mayors]] in support of the Filipino Veterans Act.<ref>http://www.usmayors.org/resolutions/75th_conference/uep_07.asp</ref> The Cabaldon resolution was adopted by unanimous vote.
On January 17, 2008, Senators [[Daniel Inouye]] and [[Theodore Stevens]] made a [[courtesy call]] on President [[Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo]] at Malacañang and assured her of the early passage of the Filipino Veterans Equity Bill to benefit 18,000 surviving [[World War II]] veterans. Executive secretary [[Eduardo Ermita]], defense secretary Gilbert Teodoro, acting foreign affairs secretary Francisco Benedicto, Armed Forces chief of staff Gen. Hermogenes Esperon, Jr., US Ambassador [[Kristie Kenney]], and US Deputy Chief of Mission [[Paul W. Jones|Paul Jones]]. Arroyo conferred the Order of the Golden Heart with the Rank of [[Grand Cross]] on Stevens contributing to "the amelioration and improvement of the moral, social, and economic conditions of the Filipino people."<ref>[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-01/06/content_7374464.htm news.xinhuanet.com, Philippine official: U.S. Congress to vote on Filipino WWII veterans payment bill]</ref><ref>[http://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2008/01/07/18470785.php www.indybay.org, JFAV Asks De Venecia to Stop Raising False Hopes on Equity Bill]</ref>
==Support by Lao and Hmong-American Veterans, and Other NGOs in Washington==
The Filipino veterans efforts in Washington, D.C., and in the [[US Congress]], have been repeatedly supported by Hmong- and Lao-American veterans groups who served with U.S. forces during the [[Vietnam War]] in [[Kingdom of Laos]], as well as various non-profit, and non-governmental organizations ([[NGO]])s, including the [[Lao Veterans of America]], Inc.<ref>Smith, Philip, Lao Veterans of America, Inc., Washington, D.C. (04 April 1997), http://www.laoveteransofamerica.org</ref>

[[File:Pokie machine in New Zealand.jpg|right|thumb|A pokie machine in a New Zealand pub.]] [[Gambling]] in [[New Zealand]] is controlled by the [[Department of Internal Affairs]]. All public gambling is expected to return a portion of profits to the community. The largest proportion of the gambling industry is operated by state-owned institutions. Expenditure on gambling (losses experienced by players) was $NZ 2.034 billion in 2008 ($NZ 480 per capita), a tenfold increase over 1985 figures.<ref name=stats>{{cite web|url=http://www.dia.govt.nz/Pubforms.nsf/URL/Expendstats08.pdf/$file/Expendstats08.pdf|title=GAMBLING EXPENDITURE STATISTICS 1984-2008|publisher=Department of Internal Affairs |accessdate=2009-07-01}}</ref>
==Horse racing== [[Bookmaking]] was declared illegal in New Zealand in 1920.<ref name="stats1">{{cite web |url=http://www.stats.govt.nz/products-and-services/Articles/gaming-industry-Sep99.htm |title=Gambling: An Economically Significant Industry |date=September 1999 |publisher=Statistics New Zealand |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090504084841/http://www.stats.govt.nz/products-and-services/Articles/gaming-industry-Sep99.htm |archivedate=4 May 2009 |df=dmy }}</ref> From then until the introduction of the [[Totalizator Agency Board]] (TAB) in 1961, betting on racing was only available on-course.
==Lotteries== The first "Art Union" was conducted in New Zealand by the Otago Art Society in December 1877,<ref>See Grey River Argus, 20 Dec 1877, page 2)</ref> Both individuals and organizations subsequently used them as a way of raising funds. The first national lotteries were established in 1933. They were known as "Art Unions". Prizes were relatively small, and in the early Art Unions the prizes were quantities of alluvial gold. As an example, the "Golden Treasure" Art Union of 1935 had 200,000 tickets with a top prize of £2000 ranging down to an 11th prize of £20 plus 400 prizes of £2.<ref>{{cite web|title=Golden Treasure Art Union Results.|work=The New Zealand Railways Magazine, Volume 10, Issue 5|date=1 August 1935|publisher=NZ Electronic Text Centre|url=http://www.nzetc.org/tm/scholarly/tei-Gov10_05Rail-t1-body-d13-d2.html}}</ref> The low returns tempted many people to (illegally) purchase tickets in overseas lotteries such as the Australian [[Tatts Group Limited|Tattersall's]] lottery. With Art Union sales declining, a review of lotteries was undertaken by the Second Labour Government in the late 1950s, and in 1961 the National Government introduced the [[Golden Kiwi]] lottery.<ref>[http://www.nzhistory.net.nz/timeline&new_date=12/12 NZ History.net - first Golden kiwi Lottery]</ref>
The [[New Zealand Lotteries Commission]] was established in 1987. Its original product, [[Lottery|Lotto]], has since been supplemented by [[Instant Kiwi]] [[scratch card]]s, daily [[Keno]] and a Lotto variant named Big Wednesday. Lotto tickets became available online in 2008.
The [[Totalizator Agency Board]], commonly called the TAB, is a [[sports betting]] organisation run by the [[New Zealand Racing Board]].
=="Pokies"== Introduced in 1987, [[slot machine]]s, commonly known as "pokies", are operated by charitable foundations and are mostly placed in hotels and bars. Maximum jackpots are regulated. In the year ending 30 June 2008, turnover was $10.096 billion, of which $9.158 billion was returned as prizes (player losses were $938 million). These figures represent a 9% decrease from the peak year of 2004. Pokies accounted for 46.1% of gambling expenditure (losses) in 2008.<ref name="stats" /> The year to 30 June 2009 saw a further 5% fall in expenditure, to $889 million. There were 19,479 machines in 1,501 venues operated by 384 licensees, all of these figures being a decrease from 2008.<ref name=stuff>{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/2593281/Pokie-machine-spending-down-to-seven-year-low|title=Pokie machine spending down to seven-year low|publisher=NZPA|accessdate=2009-07-14|date=2009-07-14}}</ref>
Since 1 July 2009, all machines must have Player Information Displays, which inform the gambler how long they have been playing, how much they have lost, and which encourage them to take breaks.<ref name="stuff" />
A 2010 study linked the prevalence of slot machines with high crime levels.{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}}<!-- try references from http://www.pgfnz.org.nz/Uploads/PDFDocs/Crime_and_gambling_June_2010.pdf -->
In May 2013 the Government announced it would allow casino [[SkyCity Auckland]] to install an additional 230 pokie machines and 40 new gambling tables, in exchange for a $402 million convention centre.<ref>{{cite news| url= http://tvnz.co.nz/politics-news/skycity-convention-centre-set-create-800-jobs-joyce-5435254|work=TV NZ|title= SkyCity convention centre set to create 800 jobs - Joyce| date=May 13, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/8664618/Green-Party-threatens-SkyCity-law-repeal|work= Stuff.co.nz | title= SkyCity's pokie full house | date=May 13, 2013}}</ref>
==Casinos== There are six [[casino]]s operating in New Zealand, the first of which opened in 1994: *[[Dunedin Casino]] *[[Christchurch Casino]] *[[SkyCity Auckland]] *[[Skycity Hamilton|SKYCITY Hamilton]] *[[SKYCITY Queenstown]] *SKYCITY Wharf Casino
==See also== *[[Problem gambling]] *[[Problem Gambling Foundation of New Zealand]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== *Curtis, Bruce (c2002) ''Gambling in New Zealand'' Dunmore Press {{ISBN|0-86469-404-0}}
==External links== *[http://www.dia.govt.nz/diawebsite.nsf/wpg_URL/Services-Casino-and-Non-Casino-Gaming-Index?OpenDocument#three Gambling information page] at the [[Department of Internal Affairs (New Zealand)|Department of Internal Affairs]] *[http://www.dia.govt.nz/diawebsite.nsf/wpg_URL/Resource-material-Our-Policy-Advice-Areas-Gaming-Policy?OpenDocument Gaming policy] - Department of Internal Affairs *[http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/2003/0051/latest/DLM207497.html Gambling Act 2003] - text of the Act *[http://www.gamblingwatch.org.nz GamblingWatch] {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2011}}

'''Greenhouse gas emissions accounting''' is a method of calculating the amount of greenhouse gases (GHG) emitted by a region in a given time-scale. A National [[Emission inventory|Emissions Inventory]] (NEI) measuring a country’s GHG emissions in a year is required by the [[UNFCCC]] to provide a benchmark for the country’s emission reductions, and subsequently to evaluate international climate policies such as the [[Kyoto protocol]] (although the original has now expired, extensions have been agreed) as well as regional climate policies such as the [[EU Emissions Trading Scheme]] (ETS).<ref name="Peters et al 2011">{{cite journal|last=Peters|first=G.P.|author2=Minx, J.C. |author3=Weber, C.L. |author4=Edenhofer, O |title=Growth in emission transfers via international trade from 1990 to 2008|journal=PNAS|year=2011|volume=108|issue=21|doi=10.1073/pnas.1006388108|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2011/04/19/1006388108.abstract |pages=8903–8908 |pmid=21518879 |pmc=3102371}}</ref>
There are two conflicting ways of measuring GHG emissions: production-based (sometimes referred to as territorial-based) or consumption-based. Production-based emissions take place “within national territory and offshore areas over which the country has jurisdiction”.<ref name="IPCC 2006">{{cite book|title=) IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories|year=2006|publisher=Institute for Global Environmental Strategies|location=Japan|page=7|url=http://www.ipcc-nggip.iges.or.jp/public/2006gl/vol1.html|author=Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change}}</ref> Consumption-based emissions encompass those emissions from domestic final consumption and those caused by the production of its imports.<ref name="Peters and Hertwich 2008a.">{{cite journal|last=Peters|first=G.P.|author2=Hertwich, Edgar G.|title=Post-Kyoto greenhouse gas inventories: production versus consumption|journal=Climatic Change|year=2008|volume=86|doi=10.1007/s10584-007-9280-1|pages=51–66}}</ref><ref name="Boitier 2012">{{cite journal|last=Boitier|first=B.|title=CO<sub>2</sub> emissions production-based accounting vs consumption: Insights from the WIOD databases|year=2012|series=WIOD Conference Paper, April|url=http://www.wiod.org/conferences/groningen/paper_Boitier.pdf}}</ref> This means the importing country takes responsibility for emissions related to production of the exporting country’s exports. By these definitions production-based emissions include exports but exclude imports and emissions embodied in international trade, whereas consumption-based emissions refer to the reverse (Table 1).
Which technique is applied by [[policymakers]] is fundamental as each can generate a very different NEI.<ref name="Boitier 2012" /> Different NEIs would result in a country’s choosing different optimal [[Environmental mitigation|mitigation activities]], the wrong choice based on wrong information being potentially damaging.<ref name="Peters 2008">{{cite journal|last=Peters|first=G.P.|title=From Production-based to consumption-based national emission inventories|journal=Ecological Economics|year=2008|volume=65|issue=1|doi=10.1016/j.ecolecon.2007.10.014|pages=13–23}}</ref> The application of production-based emissions accounting is currently favoured in policy terms, although much of the literature favours consumption-based accounting. The former method is criticised in the literature principally for its inability to allocate emissions embodied in international trade/transportation and the potential for [[carbon leakage]].<ref name="Peters and Hertwich 2008a." />
== Rationale == {| class="wikitable" | align="right" | style="width:35%;font-size:90%" |+ align="bottom" | Table 1. A comparison of the production-based and consumption-based NEI.<ref name="Peters 2008" /> |- ! scope="col" width="33%" | Criteria ! scope="col" width="33%" |Production-based NEI ! scope="col" width="34%" |Consumption-based NEI |- | Emissions covered||align="center" |Administered territory|| align="center" |Global |- | Allocation|| align="center" |Domestic production|| align="center" |Domestic consumption |- | Allocation of trade|| align="center" |Includes exports, not imports|| align="center" |Includes imports, not exports |- | Mitigation focus|| align="center" |Domestic activities including exports|| align="center" |Domestic activities and imports (exports excluded) |- | Comparability|| align="center" |Consistent with GDP|| align="center" |Consistent with national consumption |- | Consistent with trade policy|| align="center" |No|| align="center" |Yes |- | Annex I emissions coverage|| align="center" |Lower|| align="center" |Higher |- | Complexity|| align="center" |Low|| align="center" |High |- | Transparency|| align="center" |High|| align="center" |Low |- | Uncertainty|| align="center" |Lower || align="center" |Higher |- | Current country coverage|| align="center" |Relatively high|| align="center" |Low with current data |- | Mitigation analysis|| align="center" |Domestic mitigation only|| align="center" |Global mitigation |} It is now overwhelmingly accepted that the release of GHG, predominantly from the [[Anthropogenic hazard|anthropogenic]] burning of [[fossil fuels]] and the release of direct emissions from agricultural activities, is accelerating the growth of these gases in the atmosphere resulting in [[climate change]].<ref name="Canadell et al 2007">{{cite journal|last=Canadell|first=J.G. |author2=Le Quéré, C. |author3=Raupacha, M.R. |author4=Fielde, C.B. |author5=Buitenhuisc, E.T. |author6=Ciaisf, P. |title=Contributions to accelerating atmospheric CO<sub>2</sub> growth from economic activity, carbon intensity, and efficiency of natural sinks|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|year=2007|volume=104|issue=47|doi=10.1073/pnas.0702737104|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/104/47/18866.full.pdf+html|pmid=17962418|pmc=2141868|display-authors=etal |pages=18866–18870}}</ref> Over the last few decades emissions have grown at an increasing rate from 1.0% yr<sup>−1</sup> throughout the 1990s to 3.4% yr<sup>−1</sup> between 2000 and 2008.<ref name="Le Quere et al 2012">{{cite journal|last=Le Quéré|first=C.|author2=Raupach, M.R. |author3=Canadell, J.G. |author4=Marland, G. |author5=Bopp, L.|title=Trends in the sources and sinks of carbon dioxide|journal=Nature Geoscience|year=2012|volume=2|doi=10.1038/ngeo689|url=http://www.nature.com/ngeo/journal/v2/n12/abs/ngeo689.html|issue=12|display-authors=etal |pages=831–836}}</ref> These increases have been driven not only by a growing [[global population]] and [[GDP|per-capita GDP]], but also by global increases in the [[energy intensity]] of GDP (energy per unit GDP) and the [[carbon intensity]] of energy (emissions per unit energy).<ref name="Raupach et al 2007">{{cite journal|last=Raupach|first=M. R. |author2=Marland, G. |author3=Ciais, P. |author4=Le Quere, C. |author5=Canadell, J. G. |title=Global and regional drivers of accelerating CO<sub>2</sub> emissions|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|year=2007|volume=104|issue=24|doi=10.1073/pnas.0700609104|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/104/24/10288.full.pdf+html|pmid=17519334|pmc=1876160|display-authors=etal |pages=10288–10293}}</ref><ref name="Le Quere et al 2012" /><ref name="Davis and Caldeira 2010">{{cite journal|last=Davis|first=S.J.|author2=Caldeira, K.|title=Consumption-based accounting of CO<sub>2</sub> emissions|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|year=2010|volume=107|issue=12|doi=10.1073/pnas.0906974107|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2010/02/23/0906974107.abstract|bibcode=2010PNAS..107.5687D|pages=5687–5692|pmc=2851800}}</ref> These drivers are most apparent in [[Developing countries|developing markets]] (Kyoto non-Annex B countries), but what is less apparent is that a substantial fraction of the growth in these countries is to satisfy the demand of consumers in [[developed countries]] (Kyoto Annex B countries).<ref name="Davis and Caldeira 2010" /> This is exaggerated by a process known as [[Carbon leakage|Carbon Leakage]] whereby Annex B countries decrease domestic production in place of increased importation of products from non-Annex B countries where emission policies are less strict. Although this may seem the rational choice for consumers when considering local pollutants, consumers are inescapably affected by global pollutants such as GHG, irrespective of where production occurs.<ref name="Peters and Hertwich 2008b">{{cite journal|last=Peters|first=G.P.|author2=Hertwich, E.G.|title=CO<sub>2</sub> Embodied in International Trade with Implications for Global Climate Policy|journal=Environmental Science & Technology|year=2008|volume=42|issue=5|doi=10.1021/es072023k|url=http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/es072023k|pages=1401–1407}}</ref> Although emissions have slowed since 2007 as a result of the global financial crisis, the longer term trend of increased emissions is likely to resume.
Today, much international effort is put into slowing the anthropogenic release of GHG and resulting climate change. In order to set benchmarks and emissions targets for - as well as monitor and evaluate the progress of - international and regional policies, the accurate measurement of each country’s NEI becomes imperative.
{{See also|Life-cycle greenhouse-gas emissions of energy sources}}
== Measuring GHG emissions ==
=== Production-based accounting === As production-based emissions accounting is currently favoured in policy terms, its methodology is well established. Emissions are calculated not directly but indirectly from fossil fuel usage and other relevant processes such as industry and agriculture according to 2006 guidelines issued by the [[IPCC]] for GHG reporting.<ref name="IPCC 2006" /><ref name="National Audit Office">{{cite web|last=National Audit Office (2008)|title=UK greenhouse gas emissions: measurement and reporting|url=http://www.nao.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/0708_greenhouse_gas_emissions.pdf|access-date=3 July 2013}}</ref> The guidelines span numerous methodologies dependent on the level of sophistication (Tiers 1-3 in Table 2). The simplest methodology combines the extent of a human activity with a coefficient quantifying the emissions from that activity, known as an ‘emission factor’.<ref name="Eurostat 2010">{{cite book|last=Wieland|first=ed.-in-chief: Ulrich|title=Using official statistics to calculate greenhouse gas emissions : a statistical guide|year=2010|publisher=Publications Office of the European Union|location=Luxembourg: Publications Office of the European Union|isbn=978-92-79-14487-5|url=http://epp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/cache/ITY_OFFPUB/KS-31-09-272/EN/KS-31-09-272-EN.PDF|edition=2010}}</ref> For example to estimate emissions from the energy sector (typically contributing over 90% of CO2 emissions and 75% of all GHG emissions in developed countries) the quantity of fuels combusted is combined with an emission factor - the level of sophistication increasing with the accuracy and complexity of the emission factor.<ref name="IPCC 2006" /> Table 2 outlines how the UK implements these guidelines to estimate some of its emissions-producing activities. {| class="wikitable" | style="font-size:90%" |+align="bottom" | Table 2. Some emissions producing activities and methods used to estimate emissions. IPCC tier represents one of three tiers, each tier indicating an additional layer of sophistication. These tiers indicate which method of emissions calculations is used from the IPCC 1996 Guidelines.<ref name="National Audit Office" /> |- ! Activity !! GHG !! IPCC Tier !! Method used to estimate emissions |- | Public electricity and heat production|| align="center" |CO<sub>2</sub>||align="center" | 2|| An emissions factor is applied to fuel consumption data from DUKES. Some data are also collected from individual point sources at generation facilities. The emissions factors are UK specific factors obtained by sampling average UK carbon content of fuels. |- | Road transportation|| align="center" |CO<sub>2</sub>, CH<sub>4</sub>, N<sub>2</sub>O||align="center" | 3|| Emissions from road transport are estimated from a combination of total fuel consumption data taken from the Digest of UK Energy Statistics and fuel properties, and from a combination of drive related emission factors and road traffic data on fuel use, car type, miles driven, road types, and fuel type from the [[Department for Transport]]. |- | Domestic aviation||align="center" | CO<sub>2</sub>, CH<sub>4</sub>, N<sub>2</sub>O|| align="center" |3|| Data from the Department for Transport and [[National aviation authority|CAA]] on aircraft movements is broken down by aircraft type at each UK airport. The model takes into account the lengths of time spent on different parts of an aircraft’s take off and landing cycle and different types of aircraft used in the UK. |- | Refrigeration and air conditioning equipment|| align="center" |HFC||align="center" | 2|| Data on the numbers of UK domestic and commercial refrigerators is obtained from the UK Market Transformation Programme and activity data supplied by industry. Data on mobile air conditioning systems is obtained from the UK [[Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders]]. Once the numbers and size of refrigerators is known, an emissions factor which was derived to reflect UK refrigeration fluids applied to estimate emissions |- | [[Enteric fermentation|Enteric Fermentation]]|| align="center" |CH<sub>4</sub>||align="center" | 2|| Enteric fermentation is a digestive process in ruminant animals which produces [[methane]]. Emissions are estimated from animal production data from the June agricultural census. Emissions factors for milk producing cattle, lambs and deer are calculated using a tier 2 approach which takes into account the sizes, ages and types of UK animals. |- | Agricultural soils|| align="center" |N<sub>2</sub>0|| align="center" |1 and 2|| The method involves estimating the contributions from the use of inorganic fertilizer, biological fixation of nitrogen by crops, ploughing in crop residues, cultivation of organic soils, spreading animal manure on land, and manures dropped by animals grazing in the field using data from [[DEFRA]] and the British Survey of Fertiliser Practice. For some of these areas IPCC default methods are used and for others UK specific methods are used. |- | Wastewater handling|| align="center" |CH<sub>4</sub>, N<sub>2</sub>O|| align="center" |2|| The estimate is based on the work of Hobson et al. (1996) who estimated emissions of methane for the years 1990-95. Subsequent years are extrapolated on the basis of population. Sewage disposed to landfill is included in landfill emissions |}
=== Consumption-based accounting === Consumption-based emissions accounting has an equally established methodology using Input-Output Tables. These “display the interconnection between different sectors of production and allow for a tracing of the production and consumption in an economy”<ref name="Hertwich 2010 3">{{cite journal|last=Hertwich|first=E.G.|author2=Peters, G.P.|title=Mutiregional Input-Output Database. OPEN: EU Technical Document.|pages=3|year=2010|url=http://www.oneplaneteconomynetwork.org/resources/programme-documents/WP1_MRIO_Technical_Document.pdf|publisher=One planet economy network.|location=Godalming}}</ref> and were originally created for national economies. However, as production has become increasingly international and the import/export market between nations has flourished, Multi-Regional Input-Output (MRIO) models have been developed. The unique feature of MRIO is allowing a product to be traced across its production cycle, “quantifying the contributions to the value of the product from different economic sectors in various countries represented in the model. It hence offers a description of the global supply chains of products consumed”.<ref name="Hertwich 2010 3"/> From this, assuming regional- and industry-specific data for CO<sub>2</sub> emissions per unit of output are available, the total amount of emissions for the product can be calculated, and therefore the amount of emissions the final consumer is allocated responsibility for.<ref name="Davis and Caldeira 2010" />
The two methodologies of emissions accounting begin to expose their key differences. Production-based accounting is transparently consistent with GDP, whereas consumption-based accounting (more complex and uncertain) is consistent with national consumption and trade. However, the most important difference is that the later covers global emissions - including those ‘embodied’ emissions that are omitted in production-based accounting - and offers globally based mitigation options.<ref name="Peters and Hertwich 2008a." /> Thus the attribution of emissions embodied in international trade is the crux of the matter.<ref name="Davis and Caldeira 2010" />
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Davis and Caldeira World Trade Flux Map.png|thumbnail|right|upright=2.0|Figure 1. Largest international fluxes of emissions embodied in trade (Mt CO<sub>2</sub> y<sup>−1</sup>) from dominant net exporting countries (blue) to the dominant net importing countries (red) in 2004.<ref name="Davis and Caldeira 2010" />]] -->
== Emissions embodied in international trade == Figure 1 and Table 3 show extent of emissions embodied in international trade and thus their importance when attempting emissions reductions. Figure 1 shows the international trade flows of the top 10 countries with largest trade fluxes in 2004 and illustrates the dominance of trade from developing countries (principally China, Russia and India) to developed countries (principally USA, EU and Japan). Table 3 supports this showing that the traded emissions in 2008 total 7.8 gigatonnes (Gt) with a net CO<sub>2</sub> emissions trade from developing to developed countries of 1.6 Gt.
Table 3 also shows how these processes of production, consumption and trade have changed from 1990 (commonly chosen for baseline levels) to 2008. Global emissions have risen 39%, but in the same period developed countries seem to have stabilized their domestic emissions, whereas developing countries’ domestic emissions have doubled. This ‘stabilization’ is arguably misleading, however, if the increased trade from developing to developed countries is considered. This has increased from 0.4 Gt CO<sub>2</sub> to 1.6 Gt CO<sub>2</sub> - a 17%/year average growth meaning 16 Gt CO<sub>2</sub> have been traded from developing to developed countries between 1990-2008. Assuming a proportion of the increased production in developing countries is to fulfil the consumption demands of developed countries, the process known as carbon leakage becomes evident. Thus, including international trade (i.e. the methodology of consumption-based accounting) reverses the apparent decreasing trend in emissions in developed countries, changing a 2% decrease (as calculated by production-based accounting) into a 7% increase across the time period.<ref name="Caldeira and Davis 2011">{{cite journal|last=Caldeira|first=K.|author2=Davis, S.J.|title=Accounting for carbon dioxide emissions: A matter of time|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|year=2011|volume=108|issue=21|doi=10.1073/pnas.1106517108|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/108/21/8533.full|pages=8533–8534|pmc=3102393}}</ref> This point is only further emphasized when these trends are studied at a less aggregated scale. {| class="wikitable" | style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto;font-size:90%" |+ align="bottom" |Table 3. Allocation of global emissions to Annex B and non-Annex B countries separated into domestic and internationally traded components.<ref name="Peters et al 2011" /> |- ! !! Component !! 1990 (Gt CO<sub>2</sub>) !! 2008 (Gt CO<sub>2</sub>) !! Growth (%/y) |- | align="center" |'''Annex B'''|| || || || |- | Domestic|| Annex B Domestic (Bdom)|| align="center" | 11.3|| align="center" | 10.8|| align="center"| -0.3 |- | Trade component|| Annex B to Annex B (B2B)|| align="center" |2.1||align="center" | 2.2|| align="center" |0.2 |- | || Annex B to non-Annex B (B2nB)|| align="center" |0.7|| align="center" |0.9|| align="center" | 1.8 |- | Production|| Annex B production (Bprod = Bdom + B2B + B2nB)|| align="center" |14.2|| align="center" |13.9|| align="center" |-0.1 |- | Consumption|| Annex B consumption (Bcons = Bdom + B2B + nB2B)|| align="center" |14.5|| align="center" | 15.5|| align="center" |0.3 |- | align="center" |'''Non-Annex B'''|| || || || |- | Domestic|| Non-Annex B domestic (nBdom)|| align="center" |6.2|| align="center" |11.7|| align="center" |4.6 |- | Trade component|| Non-Annex B to Annex B (nB2B)|| align="center" |1.1|| align="center" |2.6|| align="center" |7.0 |- | || Non-Annex B to non-Annex B (nB2nB)|| align="center" |0.4|| align="center" |2.2|| align="center" |21.5 |- | Production|| Non-Annex B production (nBprod = nBdom + nB2B + nB2nB)|| align="center" |7.7|| align="center" | 16.4|| align="center" |5.9 |- | Consumption|| Non-Annex B consumption (nBcons = nBdom + B2nB + nB2nB)|| align="center" |7.4|| align="center" |14.8|| align="center" | 5.3 |- | align="center" |'''Trade totals'''|| Traded emissions (B2B + B2nB + nB2B + nB2nB)|| align="center" |4.3|| align="center" |7.8|| align="center" |4.3 |- | || Trade balance (B2nB − nB2B)|| align="center" |-0.4|| align="center" |-1.6|| align="center" |16.9 |- | || Global emissions (Bprod + nBprod = Bcons + nBcon)|| align="center" |21.9|| align="center" |30.3|| align="center" |2.0 |}
Figure 2 shows the percentage surplus of emissions as calculated by production-based accounting over consumption-based accounting. In general, production-based accounting proposes lower emissions for the [[European Union|EU]] and [[OECD]] countries (developed countries) and higher emissions for [[BRIC]] and [[Rest of the world|RoW]] (developing countries). However, consumption-based accounting proposes the reverse with lower emissions in BRIC and RoW, and higher emissions in EU and OECD countries.<ref name="Boitier 2012" /> This led Boitier<ref name="Boitier 2012 p8">{{cite journal|last=Boitier|first=B.|title=CO<sub>2</sub> emissions production-based accounting vs consumption: Insights from the WIOD databases|pages=8|year=2012|series=WIOD Conference Paper, April|url=http://www.wiod.org/conferences/groningen/paper_Boitier.pdf}}</ref> to term EU and OECD ‘CO<sub>2</sub> consumers’ and BRIC and RoW ‘CO<sub>2</sub> producers’.
The large difference in these results is corroborated by further analysis. The [[European Union|EU-27]] in 1994 counted emissions using the consumption-based approach at 11% higher than those counted using the production-based approach, this difference rising to 24% in 2008. Similarly OECD countries reached a peak variance of 16% in 2006 whilst dropping to 14% in 2008. In contrast, although RoW starts and ends relatively equal, in the intervening years it is a clear CO<sub>2</sub> producer, as are BRIC with an average consumption-based emissions deficit of 18.5% compared to production-based emissions.
Peters and Hertwich<ref name="Peters and Hertwich 2008b" /> completed a MRIO study to calculate emissions embodied in international trade using data from the 2001 Global Trade Analysis Program (GTAP). After manipulation, although their numbers are slightly more conservative (EU 14%; OECD 3%; BRIC 16%; RoW 6%) than Boitier<ref name="Boitier 2012" /> the same trend is evident - developed countries are CO<sub>2</sub> consumers and developing countries are CO<sub>2</sub> producers. This trend is seen across the literature and supporting the use of consumption-based emissions accounting in policy-making decisions. <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Boitier Consumption model of the world.png|thumbnail|right|upright=2.0|Figure 2. Consumption-based emission CO<sub>2</sub> surplus compared to production-based CO<sub>2</sub> from 1995-2008<ref name="Boitier 2012" />]] -->
== Consumption-based accounting ==
=== Advantages === Consumption-based emissions accounting may be deemed superior as it incorporates embodied emissions currently ignored by the UNFCCC preferred production-based accounting. Other key advantages include: extending mitigation options, covering more global emissions through increased participation, and inherently encompassing policies such as the [[Clean Development Mechanism]] (CDM).<ref name="Peters 2008" />
==== Extending mitigation options ==== Under the production-based system a country is punished for having a pollution intensive resource base. If this country has pollution intensive exports, such as Norway where 69% of its CO<sub>2</sub> emissions are the result of production for export,<ref name="Peters and Hertwich 2006a">{{cite journal|last=Peters|first=G.P.|author2=Hertwich, E.G.|title=Structural analysis of international trade: environmental impacts of Norway|journal=Economic Systems Research|year=2006|volume=18|issue=2|doi=10.1080/09535310600653008|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/09535310600653008#.UfbQM43WTX4|pages=155–181}}</ref> a simple way to meet its emissions reductions set out under Kyoto would be to reduce its exports. Although this would be environmentally advantageous, it would be economically and politically harmful as exports are an important part of a country’s GDP.<ref name="Peters 2008" /> However, by having appropriate mechanisms in place, such as a [[Carbon tax#Harmonized carbon taxes|harmonized global tax]], [[Carbon tax#Border adjustments, tariffs and bans|border-tax adjustment or quotas]], a consumption-based accounting system could shift the [[comparative advantage]] towards a decision that includes environmental factors.<ref name="Peters and Hertwich 2006b">{{cite journal|last=Peters|first=G.P.|author2=Hertwich, E.G.|title=Pollution embodied in trade: The Norwegian case|journal=Global Environmental Change|year=2006|volume=16|issue=4|doi=10.1016/j.gloenvcha.2006.03.001|pages=379–387}}</ref> The tax most discussed is based on the carbon content of the fossil fuels used to produce and transport the product, the greater the level of carbon used the more tax being charged. If a country did not voluntarily participate then a border tax could be imposed on them.<ref name="Peters and Hertwich 2008a." /> This system would have the effect of embedding the cost of environmental load in the price of the product and therefore market forces would shift production to where it is economically and environmentally preferable, thus reducing GHG emissions.
==== Increasing participation ====
In addition to reducing emissions directly this system may also alleviate [[competitiveness#National competitiveness|competitiveness]] concerns in twofold ways: firstly, domestic and foreign producers are exposed to the same carbon tax; and secondly, if multiple countries are competing for the same export market they can promote environmental performance as a marketing tool.<ref name="Peters and Hertwich 2008a." /> A loss of competitiveness resulting from the absence of legally binding commitments for non-Annex B countries was the principal reason the USA and Australia, two heavily emitting countries, did not originally ratify the [[Kyoto protocol]] (Australia later ratified in 2007).<ref name="Tjernshaugen 2005">{{cite journal|last=Tjernshaugen|first=A.|title=United States participation in future climate agreements: an assessment|journal=CICERO Policy Note 2005:01, CICERO|year=2005|url=https://www.duo.uio.no/handle/10852/32742}}</ref> By alleviating such concerns more countries may participate in future climate policies resulting in a greater percentage of global emissions being covered by legally binding reduction policies. Furthermore, as developed countries are currently expected to reduce their emissions more than developing countries, the more emissions are (fairly) attributed to developed countries the more they become covered by legally bound reduction policies. Peters<ref name="Peters 2008" /> argues that this last prediction means that consumption-based accounting would advantageously result in greater emissions reductions irrespective of increased participation.
==== Encompassing policies such as the CDM ====
The [[Clean Development Mechanism|CDM]] is a flexible mechanism set up under the Kyoto Protocol with the aim of creating ‘[[Carbon Credits]]’ for trade in trading schemes such as the [[EU ETS]]. Despite coming under heavy criticism (see Evans,<ref name="Evans 2012">{{cite book|last=Evans|first=J.|title=Environmental governance|year=2012|publisher=Routledge|location=London|isbn=0415589827|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Environmental_Governance.html?id=KEU8YgEACAAJ&redir_esc=y|edition=1st}}</ref> p134-135; and Burniaux et al.,<ref name="Burniaux et al 2009">{{cite journal|last=Burniaux|first=J.M.|author2=Chateau, J. |author3=Dellink, R. |author4=Duval, R. |author5=Jamet, S. |title=The economics of climate change mitigation: how to build the necessary global action in a cost-effective manner|journal=Economics Department Working Papers|year=2009|volume=701|url=http://search.oecd.org/officialdocuments/displaydocumentpdf/?doclanguage=en&cote=eco/wkp(2009)42}}</ref> p58-65), the theory is that as the marginal cost of environmental abatement is lower in non-Annex B countries a scheme like this will promote [[technology transfer]] from Annex B to non-Annex B countries resulting in cheaper emissions reductions. Because under consumption-based emissions accounting a country is responsible for the emissions caused by its imports, it is important for the importing country to encourage good environmental behaviour and promote the cleanest production technologies available in the exporting country.<ref name="Peters and Hertwich 2008a." /> Therefore, unlike the Kyoto Protocol where the CDM was added later, consumption-based emissions accounting inherently promotes clean development in the foreign country because of the way it allocates emissions. One loophole that remains relevant is ‘[[Carbon emission trading#Criticisms|carbon colonialism]]’ whereby developed countries do not mitigate the underlying problem but simply continue to increase consumption offsetting this by exploiting the abatement potential of developing countries.<ref name="Harvey 2007">{{cite web|last=Harvey|first=F.|title=Beware the carbon offsetting cowboys|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/dcdefef6-f350-11db-9845-000b5df10621.html#axzz2YewBjlDl|work=Financial Times|access-date=10 July 2013|year=2007}}</ref>
=== Disadvantages and implementation === Despite its advantages consumption-based emissions accounting is not without its drawbacks. These were highlighted above and in Table 1 and are principally: greater uncertainty, greater complexity requiring more data not always available, and requiring greater international collaboration.
==== Greater uncertainty and complexity ==== Uncertainty derives from three main reasons: production-based accounting is much closer to statistical sources and GDP which are more assured; the methodology behind consumption-based accounting requires an extra step over production-based accounting, this step inherently incurring further doubt; and consumption-based accounting includes data from all trading partners of a particular country which will contain different levels of accuracy.<ref name="Peters and Hertwich 2008a." /><ref name="Peters 2008" /> The bulk of data required is its second pitfall as in some countries the lack of data means consumption-based accounting is not possible. However, it must be noted levels and accuracy of data will improve as more and better techniques are developed and the scientific community produce more data sets - examples including the recently launched global databases: EORA from the University of Sydney, EXIOPOL and WIOD databases from European consortia, and the Asian IDE-JETRO.<ref name="Marques et al 2012">{{cite journal|last=Marques|first=A.|author2=Rodrigues, J. |author3=Lenzen, M. |author4=Domingos, T. |title=Income-based environmental responsibility|journal=Ecological Economics|year=2012|volume=84|doi=10.1016/j.ecolecon.2012.09.010 |pages=57–65}}</ref> In the short term it will be important to attempt to quantify the level of uncertainty more accurately.<ref name="Peters and Hertwich 2008a." />
==== Greater international co-operation ====
The third problem is that consumption-based accounting requires greater international collaboration to deliver effective results. A Government has the authority to implement policies only over emissions it directly generates. In consumption-based accounting emissions from different geo-political territories are allocated to the importing country. Although the importing country can indirectly oppose this by changing its importing habits or by applying a border tax as discussed, only by greater international collaboration, through an international dialogue such as the UNFCCC, can direct and meaningful emissions reductions be enforced.<ref name="Peters and Hertwich 2008a." />
== Sharing emissions responsibility ==
Thus far it has been implied that one must implement either production-based accounting or consumption-based accounting.<ref name="Andrew and Forgie 2008">{{cite journal|last=Andrew|first=A.R.|author2=Forgie, V.|title=A three-perspective view of greenhouse gas emission responsibilities in New Zealand|journal=Ecological Economics|year=2008|volume=68|doi=10.1016/j.ecolecon.2008.02.016|pages=194–204}}</ref> However, there are arguments that the answer lies somewhere in the middle i.e. emissions should be shared between the importing and exporting countries. This approach asserts that although it is the final consumer that ultimately initiates the production, the activities that create the product and associated pollution also contribute to the producing country’s GDP. This topic is still developing in the literature principally through works by Rodrigues et al.,<ref name="Rodrigues et al 2006">{{cite journal|last=Rodrigues|first=J.|author2=Domingos, T. |author3=Giljum, S. |author4=Schneider, F. |title=Designing an indicator of environmental responsibility|journal=Ecological Economics|year=2006|volume=59|issue=3|doi=10.1016/j.ecolecon.2005.10.002 |pages=256–266}}</ref> Lenzen et al.,<ref name="Lenzen et al 2007">{{cite journal|last=Lenzen|first=M.|author2=Murray, J. |author3=Sack, F. |author4=Wiedmann, T. |title=Shared producer and consumer responsibility — Theory and practice|journal=Ecological Economics|year=2007|volume=61|issue=1|doi=10.1016/j.ecolecon.2006.05.018 |pages=27–42}}</ref> Marques et al.<ref name="Marques et al 2012" /> as well as through empirical studies by such as Andrew and Forgie.<ref name="Andrew and Forgie 2008" /> Crucially it proposes that at each stage of the supply chain the emissions are shared by some pre-defined criteria between the different actors involved.<ref name="Marques et al 2012" />
Whilst this approach of sharing emissions responsibility seems advantageous, the controversy arises over what these pre-defined criteria should be. Two of the current front runners are Lenzen et al.<ref name="Lenzen et al 2007" /> who say “the share of responsibility allocated to each agent should be proportional to its value added” and Rodrigues et al.<ref name="Rodrigues et al 2006" /> who say it should be based on “the average between an agent's consumption-based responsibility and income-based responsibility” (quoted in Marques et al.<ref name="Marques et al 2012 p60">{{cite journal|last=Marques|first=A.|author2=Rodrigues, J. |author3=Lenzen, M. |author4=Domingos, T. |title=Income-based environmental responsibility|journal=Ecological Economics|year=2012|volume=84|pages=60|doi=10.1016/j.ecolecon.2012.09.010}}</ref>). As no criteria set has been adequately developed and further work is needed to produce a finished methodology for a potentially valuable concept.
== The future ==
Measuring a country’s GHG emissions is critical to combat climate change. It is clear that production-based emissions accounting, the currently favoured method for policy-making, significantly underestimates the level of GHG emitted by excluding emissions embodied in international trade. Implementing consumption-based accounting which includes such emissions, developed countries take a greater share of GHG emissions and consequently the low level of emissions commitments for developing countries are not as important.<ref name="Peters and Hertwich 2008a." /> Not only does consumption-based accounting encompass global emissions, it promotes good environmental behaviour and increases participation by reducing competitiveness.
Despite these advantages the shift from production-based to consumption-based accounting arguably represents a shift from one extreme to another.<ref name="Peters 2008" /> The third option of sharing responsibility between importing and exporting countries represents a compromise between the two systems. However, as yet no adequately developed methodology exists for this third way, so further study is required before it can be implemented for policy-making decisions.
Today, given its lower uncertainty, established methodology and reporting, consistency between political and environmental boundaries, and widespread implementation, it is hard to see any movement away from the favoured production-based accounting.<ref name="Peters 2008" /> However, because of its key disadvantage of omitting emissions embodied in international trade, it is clear that consumption-based accounting provides invaluable information and should at least be used as a ‘shadow’ to production-based accounting. With further work into the methodologies of consumption-based accounting and sharing emissions responsibility, both can play greater roles in the future of climate policy.
